c63de0ee-5887-435c-8671-53dc9698eb93.description: Earners of the Leading for Equity & Justice Certificate badge have the ability to lead equity-related personal, professional, and systems change within K-12 environments. Upon completion of six modules co-constructed by practicing school administrators and researchers, educators will have new knowledge and strategies to engage school communities in equity work and create better schools, better communities, and ultimately, a better world.
c63de0ee-5887-435c-8671-53dc9698eb93.name: Leading for Equity & Justice Certificate

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the 36 contact hour Leading for Equity and Justice Certificate program. Grounded in social justice leadership and culturally responsive leadership, educators receive 21st century online learning to build better relationships with students and families, rethink their policies and practices, and examine their mindsets and dispositions that impact student success. The certificate signals competence for leading personal, professional, and systems change.

6b8d4d35-a595-4c2c-ab25-20f553d6d32b.description: Earners of the Introduction to Restorative Practices and Circles badge will have an understanding of the theoretical basis for restorative practices (social discipline window, fair process, and shame) and will develop the skills to carry out the fundamental practices and strategies that support a classroom or program environment that is built on being a restorative setting, i.e. centering relationship building, community connections and repairing harm in a non-punitive way.
6b8d4d35-a595-4c2c-ab25-20f553d6d32b.name: Introduction to Restorative Practices and Circles

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Introduction to Restorative Practices and Circles course and demonstrate proficiency in use of restorative practices strategies through role plays, applied scenarios and answering written examples and questions. This program is offered in partnership with the Neutral Zone. Contact hours: 11

1d15b1a3-0de1-4ff0-86ce-f1295750403b.description: Earners of the OSHA #510 badge have the ability to define construction terms found in the OSHA Construction Standards, identify hazards which occur in the construction industry, locate and determine appropriate OSHA Construction Standards, policies, and procedures, and describe the use of the OSHA Construction Standards and regulations to supplement an ongoing safety and health program.
1d15b1a3-0de1-4ff0-86ce-f1295750403b.name: OSHA #510 Occupational Safety and Health Standards for the Construction Industry

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #510 Occupational Safety and Health Standards for the Construction Industry course. This course covers OSHA Standards, policies, and procedures in the construction industry. Topics include scope and application of the OSHA Construction Standards, construction safety and health principles, and special emphasis on those areas in construction which are most hazardous.
Earners must pass a knowledge exam with a minimum score of 80%.

2668028a-209e-4ac7-a9b8-0d379113f42e.description: Earners of the OSHA #511 badge have the ability to define general industry terms found in the OSHA General Industry Standards, identify hazards which occur in general industry, locate and determine appropriate OSHA General Industry Standards, policies, and procedures, and describe the use of OSHA General Industry Standards and regulations to supplement an ongoing safety and health program.
2668028a-209e-4ac7-a9b8-0d379113f42e.name: OSHA #511 Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry

This course covers OSHA Standards, policies, and procedures in general industry. Topics include scope and application of the OSHA General Industry Standards, general industry principles and special emphasis on those areas in general industry which are most hazardous.
Earners must pass a knowledge exam with a minimum score of 85%.

dd7e752d-8554-4f11-866d-6ff9c778b0db.description: Earners of the OSHA #502 badge have the ability to demonstrate continued professional development in their field by applying effective adult learning principles and interactive training techniques to clearly identify, define, and explain construction industry hazards and acceptable corrective measures as they continue to teach the 10- and 30-hour Construction Outreach Training Program classes.

Authorized Outreach Training Program trainers are required to attend the OSHA #502 Update for Construction Industry Outreach Trainers course once every four years (4) to maintain their trainer status.

Prior to registration, earners must provide a copy of their current Outreach Training Program trainer card or an official transcript showing successful completion of the OSHA #500 Trainer Course in OSHA Standards for Construction from their respective OSHA Training Institute Education Center, for verification of trainer status.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7505 Introduction to Incident (Accident) Investigation course. This course covers an introduction to basic accident investigation procedures and describes accident analysis techniques. Course topics include reasons for conducting accident investigations, employer responsibilities related to workplace accident investigations, and a six step accident investigation procedure.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7500 Introduction to Safety and Health Management. This course covers the effective implementation of a company's safety and health management system. The course addresses the four core elements of an effective safety and health management system and those central issues that are critical to each element's proper management. This course is an interactive training session focusing on class discussion and workshops.

866659da-c23e-4cb4-939b-62a55805b6fb.description: Mentoring 4 Life, an NSF-funded, co-curricular academic program, is designed to expose STEM graduate students to evidence-based practices in mentoring and well-being. Through interactive workshops, emotional well-being groups, and resource development, graduate students gain the tools necessary to: (1) successfully mentor diverse STEM students; (2) better manage their own emotional well-being; and (3) advocate for improved mentoring experiences within their own departments.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete OSHA #511 Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry.

Earners must have five (5) years of safety and health work experience in general industry. A degree in occupational safety and health, a Certified Safety Professional (CSP) or a Certified Industrial Hygienist (CIH) designation may be substituted for two (2) years of work related experience. Students should obtain guidance on whether they meet this requirement from the OSHA Training Institute Education Center where they intend to receive the training.
Earners must submit a Prerequisite Verification form and be approved for admission to the course.
Earners must successfully complete the OSHA #501 Trainer Course in Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry.

Earners who wish to participate as authorized trainers in the OSHA Outreach Training Program must prepare a presentation on an assigned OSHA General Industry Outreach Training Program topic individually or as part of a group and receive a minimum passing score of 50.
Earners must successfully pass a written exam at the end of the course with a minimum score of 80%.
Authorized OSHA Outreach Training Program trainers are required to attend OSHA #503 Update for General Industry Outreach Trainers at least once every four (4) years to maintain their trainer status.

3c22f259-6f9f-4a30-a278-109c2ffcd9dd.description: Earners of the Training of Trainers in Restorative Practices and Circles badge have developed the foundational-level skills required to effectively facilitate restorative practices and circles and provide training and coaching in restorative practices to others.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7105 Evacuation and Emergency Planning. This course covers OSHA requirements for emergency action and fire protection plans. Course topics include purpose and requirements of emergency action and fire prevention plans, elements of emergency evacuation plans, and features of design and maintenance of emergency exit routes. Contact hours: 4

428d05be-4325-415e-b052-89856bc0f33a.description: Earners of the OSHA #7845 will have the ability to identify OSHA requirements for recordkeeping, posting and reporting and to complete OSHA Form 300 Log of Work-Related Injuries and Illnesses, OSHA Form 300A Summary of Work-Related Injuries and Illnesses, and OSHA Form 301 Injury and Illness Incident Report.
428d05be-4325-415e-b052-89856bc0f33a.name: OSHA #7845 Recordkeeping Rule Seminar

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7845 Recordkeeping Rule Seminar course covers OSHA requirements for maintaining and posting records of occupational injuries and illnesses, and reporting specific cases to OSHA. Contact hours: 4

6165f674-d72e-4b35-b3b6-4ff7625775c5.description: Earners of the OSHA #7115 badge have the ability to explain the importance of energy control programs, procedures, training, audits and methods of controlling hazardous energy.
6165f674-d72e-4b35-b3b6-4ff7625775c5.name: OSHA #7115 Lockout/Tagout

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7115 Lockout/Tagout course. This course covers the role and responsibility of the employer to develop and implement an energy control program, or lock-out/tag-out (LOTO) for the protection of workers while performing servicing and maintenance activities on machinery and equipment. Contact hours: 7.5

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7400 Occupational Noise Exposure Standards course. This course covers OSHA occupational noise exposure standards, properties of sound, noise-induced hearing loss, noise exposure control, selection and use of hearing protection, and sound level surveys and noise dosimetry, and worker training. Classroom demonstrations of noise instrumentation and hearing protection devices are featured. Contact hours: 7.5

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete a minimum of three required and four elective courses that include a minimum of 68 contact hours of training through OTI Education Center and/or EMU courses to earn the Safety and Health Associate (SHA) – General Industry Concentration certificate.

9ae14933-a65d-464a-ba60-8e5fef61993f.description: Earners of the OSHA #7100 have the ability to explain hazardous actions and motions of various types of machinery, identify methods of safeguarding, and match identified safeguards with the applicable OSHA Machinery and Machine Guarding Standards to reduce and eliminate the potential for accidents and injuries.
9ae14933-a65d-464a-ba60-8e5fef61993f.name: OSHA #7100 Introduction to Machinery and Machine Safeguarding

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7100 Introduction to Machinery and Machine Safeguarding course. This course covers the process to identify, select and properly safeguard machinery to protect employees and others in the work area and deliver appropriate training in safe work practices. Topics include types of machinery requiring guarding, point of operation, emergency eyewash/shower requirements, hazard communication, and OSHA Machinery and Machine Guarding Standards violations. Contact hours: 4

9d3cc45a-5f70-4289-815a-2a8eca936a92.description: Earners of the OSHA #3095 badge have the ability to understand the severity of electrical current on the human body, recognize and evaluate actual and potential electrical hazards and reference the applicable OSHA Standard. Earners will also know how to determine hazard abatement measures and will understand the proper use of electrical testing equipment.
9d3cc45a-5f70-4289-815a-2a8eca936a92.name: OSHA #3095 Electrical Standards

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #3095 Electrical Standards course. Course topics include single-and three-phase systems, cord-and plug-connected and fixed equipment, grounding, ground fault circuit interrupters and safety-related work practices. Emphasis is placed on electrical hazard recognition and OSHA Standards, policies, and procedures and applicable portions of the National Electrical Code (NEC). Contact hours: 26

97f1ea8f-fbb0-4704-809f-06f3efc84487.description: Earners of the OSHA #7410 badge will understand how to manage excavation/trenching operations.
97f1ea8f-fbb0-4704-809f-06f3efc84487.name: OSHA #7410 Managing Excavation/Trenching Operations

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7410 Managing Excavation/Trenching Operations course. This course covers the requirements to manage excavation/trenching operations. Course topics include understanding OSHA excavaion requirements, excavation/trenching hazards, and control measures. Earners will also learn about soil analysis techniques and protective system requirements. Contact hours: 6.5

b7a2ed94-8762-48ae-81c8-ebce9d79e29b.description: Earners of the OSHA #2255 badge have the ability to recognize work-related musculoskeletal and nerve disorders, assess employer’s ergonomic programs, and conduct ergonomic evaluations.
b7a2ed94-8762-48ae-81c8-ebce9d79e29b.name: OSHA #2255 Principles of Ergonomics

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #2255 Principles of Ergonomics course. This course covers the use of ergonomic principles to recognize, evaluate, and control work place conditions that cause or contribute to musculoskeletal and nerve disorders, use of video display terminals, and risk factors such as vibration, temperature, material handling, repetition, and lifting and patient transfers in health care. Contact hours: 18

e6100d5c-96f4-4f29-9548-a562909717e0.description: Earners of the OSHA #521 badge have the ability to recognize basic industrial hygiene principles and practices, identify characteristics of common air contaminants, locate PELs, perform basic industrial hygiene calculations, and determine methods for hazard control and abatement.
e6100d5c-96f4-4f29-9548-a562909717e0.name: OSHA #521 OSHA Guide to Industrial Hygiene

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center

This course covers industrial hygiene practices and related OSHA regulations and procedures. Course topics include recognition, evaluation, and control of chemical, physical, biological and ergonomic hazards, Permissible Exposure Limits (PEL), OSHA health standards, respiratory protection, engineering controls, OSHA sampling protocols and strategies, and workplace health program elements. Contact hours: 26

166ac874-fbbf-48b0-a680-2dacfafd4250.name: Safety & Health Specialist (SHS) – General Industry Concentration Certificate

The program includes workshops on respirator selection, qualitative and quantitative fit testing, and the use of respiratory protection and support equipment.

82bcd394-0e4c-4dc4-b8df-94b2527c727c.name: OSHA #7205 Health Hazard Awareness

The course addresses how to identify different hazards and their exposure sites in the workplace, and how to control and abate these hazards. This course is an interactive training session focusing on class discussion and workshops. Contact hours: 6

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete a minimum of five required and four elective courses that include a minimum of 135 contact hours of training through OTI Education Center and/or EMU courses to earn the Safety and Health Specialist (SHS) – Construction Industry Concentration certificate.

fd2f2645-5594-4c68-84b4-2e0d62a21918.description: Earners of the Safety & Health Professional (SHP) – General Industry Concentration Certificate have developed the foundational-level skills needed to effectively identify and evaluate compliance with OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 Standards in a general industry setting.
fd2f2645-5594-4c68-84b4-2e0d62a21918.name: Safety & Health Professional (SHP) – General Industry Concentration Certificate

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete a minimum of six required courses that include a minimum of 118 contact hours of training through OTI Education Center and/or EMU courses to earn the Safety and Health Professional (SHP) – General Industry certificate.

a87333f5-59f2-4204-b7d0-8386107d5fe4.description: The QCI Advisory Board assists EMU PPAT in bridging professional and continuing education offerings to industry needs, providing strategic advice, consulting on the development of new and existing curriculum, providing insight into instructor and speaker selection, and discussing ways EMU PPAT can better meet the educational needs of the industry they represent. In addition to advisory roles, board members also serve as ambassadors for the program.
a87333f5-59f2-4204-b7d0-8386107d5fe4.name: Quality & Continuous Improvement (QCI) Advisory Board Member

badge_template_activities.title: Advisory Board members are industry experts representing national, regional and local organizations.

Advisory Board members (1) participate in quarterly meetings, (2) understand and promote the mission and vision of EMU PPAT, (3) provide insights into industry needs, trends, best practices and emerging themes, (4) provide guidance on course / program objectives, topics and general direction, (5) provide recommendations to improve the quality and relevancy of course materials, (6) represent students, corporate clients and other users during program reviews, and (7) serve as program ambassadors.
Advisory Board members will serve a term of three (3) years with the option to serve up to an additional three (3) years in an executive board role.

61a18565-4a3f-49c9-ae40-ea2df739eb35.description: Earners of the OSHA #3015 badge have the ability to assess their employer's compliance with the OSHA Excavation Standard, utilize soil testing methods to classify soil types, determine protective systems for excavation operations, and training requirements.
61a18565-4a3f-49c9-ae40-ea2df739eb35.name: OSHA #3015 Excavation, Trenching, and Soil Mechanics

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #3015 Excavation, Trenching, and Soil Mechanics course. This course covers the OSHA Excavation Standard and safety and health aspects of excavation and trenching. Course topics include practical soil mechanics and its relationship to the stability of shored and unshored slopes and walls of excavations, introduction of various types of shoring (wood timbers and hydraulic), soil classification, and use of protective systems. Contact hours: 20

da59da6b-6db4-4361-ab7a-bb633bf2fe89.description: Earners of the OSHA #7120 badge have the ability to utilize strategies that assure employee safety while using or producing materials that generate combustible dust and the ability to use OSHA Standards, National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Standards, and other applicable consensus standards that impact industries which generate combustible dust.
da59da6b-6db4-4361-ab7a-bb633bf2fe89.name: OSHA #7120 Introduction to Combustible Dust Hazards

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7120 Introduction to Combustible Dust Hazards course. This course covers common health hazards that are encountered in the workplace, as well as the hazards posed by combustible dust within general industry. Course topics include recognizing the hazards and risks associated with combustible dust, control of electrical installation hazards, and developing controls and strategies to prevent or mitigate combustible dust fires and explosions. Contact hours: 6.5

663b88ed-e207-4abc-9b26-7f1db507b626.description: Earners of the OSHA #2015 badge have the ability to assess compliance with OSHA hazardous materials standards, determine hazardous (classified) locations, and proper moving, storing, and handling of hazardous materials.
663b88ed-e207-4abc-9b26-7f1db507b626.name: OSHA #2015 Hazardous Materials

alignments.name: OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 General Industry Standards
OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #2015 Hazardous Materials course. This course covers OSHA General Industry Standards and other consensus and proprietary standards that relate to the use of hazardous materials. Course topics include flammable and combustible liquids, compressed gases, LP-gases and cryogenic liquids. Related processes such as spraying and dipping, and use of electrical equipment in hazardous locations are also discussed. Contact hours: 26

f9c9e48d-5d64-42d1-a0f4-96c9f08f61fb.description: Earners of the OSHA #2045 have the ability to describe common machine hazards and sources of energy, identify resources for assisting with machine guarding issues, and determine methods of control and hazard abatement, and selection of appropriate machine safe guards.
f9c9e48d-5d64-42d1-a0f4-96c9f08f61fb.name: OSHA #2045 Machinery and Machine Guarding Standards

alignments.name: OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 General Industry Standards
OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #2045 Machinery and Machine Guarding Standards course. This course covers the various types of common machinery, machine safe guards, and related OSHA regulations and procedures. Course topics include machinery processes, mechanical motions, points of operation, control of hazardous energy sources (lockout/tagout), guarding of portable powered tools, and common OSHA machine guarding violations. Contact hours: 26

6129c0f1-93a2-4b01-9046-02ffb88b1982.description: Earners of the OSHA #7005 badge understand the hazards and injuries likely to occur in public warehousing and storage operations, including encounters with powered industrial trucks, material handling, lifting and ergonomics, hazard communication, walking and working surfaces, and life safety including fire protection and evacuation.
6129c0f1-93a2-4b01-9046-02ffb88b1982.name: OSHA #7005 Public Warehousing and Storage

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7005 Public Warehousing and Storage course. Students will have the ability to recognize the potential for injuries from forklifts, material handling and lifting, exposure to hazardous substances, slips, trips, and falls and methods to control and abate these hazards. Contact hours: 7

a8f0e787-e8c8-467a-bb60-bfe7965a29a5.description: Holders of the Great Lakes OTI Education Center Lead Instructor badge are experienced occupational safety and health professionals and seasoned instructors who have met qualifying criteria established by the OSHA Directorate of Training and Education and the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center at Eastern Michigan University. They are competent in a broad range of occupational safety and health skills and have primary responsibility for maintaining course curriculum and ensuring its quality.
a8f0e787-e8c8-467a-bb60-bfe7965a29a5.name: Great Lakes OTI Education Center Lead Instructor

alignments.name: Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA)
alignments.description: With the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Congress created the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) to ensure safe and healthful working conditions for working men and women by setting and enforcing standards and by providing training, outreach, education and assistance.

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Instructor must demonstrate work experience of at least three years within the subject area for a technical course or five years of work experience within the industry for an industry-specific course such as construction, maritime, or oil and gas. This experience must be within the last ten years. Experience may include relevant academic work experience, or industry association work experience sufficient to demonstrate a working knowledge of the industry and to yield a quality course delivery.

Instructor must demonstrate occupational safety and health experience of at least three years within the industry or subject area. This experience must be within the last ten years. Two years may be waived with any of the following: CIH, CSP, Master’s degree or PhD in an occupational safety and health field.

Instructor must demonstrate the ability to effectively deliver training and education to adults. Examples may include: (1) Demonstration of two years’ experience teaching adults in a training/academic environment, or (2) Documented observation and evaluation of the instructor as capable of utilizing effective adult training techniques.

Instructors of trainer or update courses (OSHA #500, OSHA #501, OSHA #502, OSHA #503, OSHA #5400, OSHA #5401, OSHA #5600, OSHA #5602) must demonstrate successful completion of a trainer or update course. The course does not need to be within the same industry as the course the instructor will deliver. This cannot include a course in which the instructor delivers all or part of the course.

Instructor must have the ability to achieve the learning objectives for the respective OTI Education Center course being delivered. This must include both of the following: (1) Demonstration of experience teaching subject materials (2) Documented observation and evaluation of the instructor as capable of meeting course objectives

Instructor must maintain current knowledge in the subject material being presented. Outreach trainer courses and the 10- and 30-hour Outreach Training Program classes are not acceptable for maintaining knowledge in subject materials. Maintaining current knowledge includes completion of the following every five years. Occupational safety and health training course(s) reflecting a minimum of 30 hours. This cannot include training in which the instructor delivers all or part of the course.

Instructor must maintain current knowledge in the subject area of teaching adults. Maintaining current knowledge includes completion of the following every five years. Training course(s) directly related to teaching adults reflecting a minimum of seven hours. This cannot include training in which the instructor delivers all or part of the course.
Qualified instructors must submit an application with supporting documentation to the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center at Eastern Michigan University.
New instructors must complete an onboarding process prior to teaching their first class.

Instructors must adhere to OSHA Training Institute Education Center instructor policies related to code of conduct and test administration as well as legal requirements related to intellectual property, reselling restrictions and OSHA language.

dc68f78b-cf5d-496c-a4c2-72d807ae75f5.description: Earners of the OSHA #7300 badge have a basic understanding of confined space hazards, evaluating and abatement of the hazards, and determining when a confined space shall be classified as a permit-required confined space.
dc68f78b-cf5d-496c-a4c2-72d807ae75f5.name: OSHA #7300 Understanding OSHA's Permit-Required Confined Space Standard

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7300 Permit-Required Confined Space Standards course. This course covers the requirements of the OSHA Permit-Required Confined Space Standard. Course topics include safety and health hazards associated with confined space entry, and the evaluation, prevention, and abatement of these hazards. Contact hours: 7

b16de000-6ca3-4552-9bf2-aa08a7ef8175.description: Earners of the OSHA #7405 badge have an awareness level of identifying fall hazards and methods to control and abate the hazards.
b16de000-6ca3-4552-9bf2-aa08a7ef8175.name: OSHA #7405 Fall Hazard Awareness for the Construction Industry

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7405 Fall Hazard Awareness for the Construction Industry course. This course covers the identification, evaluation, prevention and control of fall hazards in the construction industry. The course focuses on falls to a lower level rather than falls to the same level resulting from slips and falls. Course topics include identifying, analyzing, and preventing fall hazards utilizing OSHA Fall Protection Standards. Contact hours: 5

88d8576d-9844-4b36-a936-b71b579e815f.description: Earners of the OSHA #7410 badge will understand the importance and duties of a competent person in excavation work and have the knowledge and skills required performing these duties.
88d8576d-9844-4b36-a936-b71b579e815f.name: OSHA #7410 Managing Excavation Hazards

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7410 Managing Excavation Hazards course. This course covers the roles and responsibilities of the employer to educate and assign a competent person to excavation sites. Course topics include understanding and application of definitions relating to the OSHA Excavation Standard, excavation hazards and control measures, soil analysis techniques, protective system requirements and emergency response. Contact hours: 6.5

6dd64542-470f-4cb9-b2d7-4cde4ba18eac.description: Earners of the OSHA #2264 badge have the ability to identify permit and non-permit required confined spaces, reference the OSHA Permit-Required Confined Spaces Standard, conduct atmospheric testing, and implement a permit-required confined space program.
6dd64542-470f-4cb9-b2d7-4cde4ba18eac.name: OSHA #2264 Permit-Required Confined Space Entry

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete OSHA #2264 Permit-Required Confined Space Entry. This course covers the safety and health hazards associated with permit-required confined space entry. Topics include recognition of confined space hazards, identification of permit and non-permit required confined spaces, use of instrumentation to evaluate atmospheric hazards, ventilation techniques, development and implementation of a confined space program, proper signage, and training requirements. Contact hours: 20

b231c0d0-b049-4d6d-87ac-6d530de53b47.description: Earners of the OSHA #7510 badge will understand OSHA operations and procedures and how to work with OSHA to prevent or reduce injuries and illnesses in their workplace.
b231c0d0-b049-4d6d-87ac-6d530de53b47.name: OSHA #7510 Introduction to OSHA for Small Businesses

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the OSHA #7510 Introduction to OSHA for Small Businesses course. This course covers an introduction to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the OSH Act for owners and managers of small businesses. Course topics include an introduction to OSHA, OSHA Standards, the inspection process, implementing a safety and health program, worker training requirements and assistance available to small businesses. Minimum student contact hours: 3.5

a279bb87-1641-4e56-a92c-0192673da8c3.description: The QCI Advisory Board assists EMU PPAT in bridging professional and continuing education offerings to industry needs, providing strategic advice, consulting on the development of new and existing curriculum, providing insight into instructor and speaker selection, and discussing ways EMU PPAT can better meet the educational needs of the industry they represent. In addition to advisory roles, board members also serve as ambassadors for the program. The Executive Board manages board activities.

Advisory Board members will serve a term of three (3) years with the option to serve up to an additional three (3) years in an executive board role.

60ffe3f9-925d-43c4-8049-12660e59a7d1.description: Holders of the Great Lakes OTI Education Center Instructor badge are experienced occupational safety and health professionals and seasoned instructors who have met qualifying criteria established by the OSHA Directorate of Training and Education and the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center at Eastern Michigan University. 60ffe3f9-925d-43c4-8049-12660e59a7d1.name: Great Lakes OTI Education Center Instructor

33449a0d-6b19-4a4c-adae-b5df585150ff.description: Earners of the Nonprofit Management Certificate have developed the foundational skills required to effectively manage nonprofit organizations.
33449a0d-6b19-4a4c-adae-b5df585150ff.name: Nonprofit Management Certificate

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the Nonprofit Management Certificate badge must complete eight courses (64 total contact hours) focused on practical knowledge and skill for nonprofit professionals.

e9f03905-3533-489b-b1d7-1ac284a304c9.description: Earners of the Capacity Building for Long Term Sustainability badge have an understanding of the importance of continuous improvement and emerging trends in the nonprofit sector, such as organizational development, program development, collaboration and community engagement, leadership development, and evaluation of effectiveness. Earners also have an understanding of best practices in these areas.
e9f03905-3533-489b-b1d7-1ac284a304c9.name: Capacity Building for Long Term Sustainability

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Capacity Building for Long Term Sustainability course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

4f5ad6ac-917c-4922-86a1-e3ebb08eca71.description: Earners of the Effective Program Development badge have an understanding of the importance of mission-driven program design and outcomes. Earners also have an understanding of needs assessment, asset identification, research-based findings of needs, inclusive program strategies, program implementation strategies, logistics, marketing, and evaluation strategies. Earners have an understanding of the need for allocation of program-related resources (staffing, space, and funding).
4f5ad6ac-917c-4922-86a1-e3ebb08eca71.name: Effective Program Development

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Effective Program Development course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

e35360af-5a96-43ea-b112-e582026a8d1c.description: Earners of the Foundations of the Nonprofit Sector badge have an understanding of the evolution and purpose of the nonprofit sector, its distinctiveness, its structure, its capacities and limitations. Earners also have an understanding of the challenges faced by the sector moving forward.
e35360af-5a96-43ea-b112-e582026a8d1c.name: Foundations of the Nonprofit Sector

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Foundations of the Nonprofit Sector course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

bb48c348-9bdf-4270-944d-7dde49dcb8da.description: Earners of the Getting the Most out of Budgeting and Financial Management badge have a foundational competency in the overall basics needed to understand the financial strength of a nonprofit organization, revenue and expenditure projections, and how to use financial data to guide decision-making. Earners also have an understanding of the importance of budgeting, estimating revenues, estimating expenditures, cash management, data collection, audits, and integrated systems.
bb48c348-9bdf-4270-944d-7dde49dcb8da.name: Getting the Most out of Budgeting and Financial Management

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Getting the Most out of Budgeting and Financial Management course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

1866c282-e5c8-4140-991a-f0b285ae3252.description: Earners of the Leading and Managing Nonprofit Organizations badge have an understanding of the management complexities associated with the nonprofit sector. Earners also have an understanding of the importance of being mission-driven, the internal and external environment of nonprofit organizations, governance and board structure, and how to build an effective governing and executive-board relationship.
1866c282-e5c8-4140-991a-f0b285ae3252.name: Leading and Managing Nonprofit Organizations

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Leading and Managing Nonprofit Organizations course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

cc3431b2-eb00-46c1-b6d8-3a338b0f071f.description: Earners of the New Directions in Fundraising badge understand what fundraising is and is not as well as the elements of the fundraising process and how these may be applied to various methods of fundraising. Earners understand donor motivation and how to write a support document in a way that appeals to the needs, wants and mission of an organization. Earners understand costs and relative merits of each of the six fundraising methods used in nonprofit organizations.
cc3431b2-eb00-46c1-b6d8-3a338b0f071f.name: New Directions in Fundraising

ae9bbc45-6c28-4f86-bca9-070decb364d2.name: OSHA #7210 Pandemic Illness Preparedness

alignments.name: OSHA Training Institute Education Center
alignments.description: As a consortium partner in the Great Lakes OSHA Education Center, Eastern Michigan University is part of a national network of non-profit organizations authorized by OSHA to deliver occupational safety and health training to all levels of workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete OSHA #7210 Pandemic Illness Preparedness. This course covers recognition of hazards and risks associated with a pandemic illness event and development of strategies to assist a business, community, or family with realistic preparation for a pandemic event. Topics include potential impact of a pandemic illness event on a business and community, critical elements of a preparedness plan, and realistic strategies for supporting continuity of operations. Contact hours: 5.5

a395adc1-c7b0-4e02-8b3f-f9af8a237f16.description: Earners of the Strategies to Promote Your Organization badge have an understanding of nonprofit organization environments from a marketing perspective. Earners recognize how most people get their information and the challenges that face nonprofits in today’s under-funded and over-crowded philanthropic marketplace by exploring networking, social media, public relations disasters, and how to manage public relations risks in today’s highly competitive environment.
a395adc1-c7b0-4e02-8b3f-f9af8a237f16.name: Strategies to Promote Your Organization

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Strategies to Promote Your Organization course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

ce897a61-0fcb-4666-8917-2f19b1153ef4.description: Earners of the Tapping the Reservoir of People badge have an understanding of the nonprofit organization workforce including the key elements of human resource management. Earners also have an understanding of volunteers and their role in nonprofit organizations as well as volunteer engagement and management.
ce897a61-0fcb-4666-8917-2f19b1153ef4.name: Tapping the Reservoir of People

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must successfully complete the Tapping the Reservoir of People course. Earners are assessed through multiple choice comprehension quizzes as well as cumulative essay questions that require critical thinking and analysis. Contact hours: 8

6295c0df-6a38-400f-b225-08bbe4c21e88.description: Earners of The Human Services Professional badge will gain an understanding of interpersonal communications as applied in three high impact human services professions: Education, Healthcare and Law Enforcement. Using basic applied research techniques, these practitioners are able to explore key cultural and social differences among service providers and resource seekers and use this knowledge to evaluate the quality and effectiveness of interpersonal communications at the point of service.

alignments.name: MI Department of Education State Continuing Education Clock Hours (SCECH)
alignments.description: State Continuing Education Clock Hours (SCECH) are hours earned by attending professional development activities provided by SCECH Sponsors and approved by the Michigan Department of Education (MDE). These hours can be used for renewal and progression of certificates and licenses issued by MDE.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must complete the 33 contact hour The Human Services Professional course. Incorporating theory, personal reflection and practical application, this interactive and engaging 12-week program is designed as a set of experiences that support a shift in thinking about how we treat each other. It includes activities to help participants better understand and more effectively engage with the individuals they serve in public facing roles in health care, law enforcement and education.
